citation.article-title: Natronobacterium gen. nov. and Natronococcus gen. nov., two new genera of haloalkaliphilic archaebacteria.

p.s: Description of Natronobacterium gen. nov.
Natronobacterium (Na.tro.no.bac.ter'ri.um. natron, derived from an Arabic noun for soda (sodium carbonate); Gr.n. bakterion, a small rod; M.L. neut. n. Natronobacterium, the soda rod)
Rods 0.5-1.0 μm by 2-15 μm.
Some strains motile.
Colonies on solid media red, 1-3 mm in diameter.
Gram-negative.
Lysis occurs in hypotonic solutions (<1.5M NaCl).
Growth occurs between 12 and 30% NaCI, optimum 20-25% NaCl.
Alkaliphilic with obligate requirement for sodium carbonate.
pH range for growth 8.5-11.0, optimum 8.5-9.5.
Optimum temperature 37-45 °C.
Require only low magnesium concentrations (<0.01M) (Tindall et al., 1980; Soliman and Truper, 1982).
Chemoorganotrophs.
Strict aerobes.
Nitrogen sources; casamino acids, glutamate.
Carbon sources; casamino acids and carbohydrates.
Catalase and oxidase positive.
Insensitive to penicillin, chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracyclin.
Sensitive to bacitracin, novobiocin, and anisomycin.
Possess core diether lipids with both C20, C20 and C20, C25 structures (de Rosa et al., 1982) and menaquinones MK8 and MK8 (H2) (Collins et al., 1981).
Do not possess glycolipids.
G + C content of DNA ranges from 61.2-64.6 mol% (buoyant density).
Some strains contain a minor DNA component of G + C content 49.7-51.9 mol%.
Habitats: highly saline soda lakes and their trona (Na2CO3 NaHCO3·2H2O) crusts.
Type species: Natronobacterium gregoryi gen.et.sp.nov.
